issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, describing the PersonController) repeatedly says that each PersonController method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter, but the rest of the materials (the template and solution code, UML and textual descriptions) expect Consumer<List<Person>>. This is an inconsistent generic type in the parameter description and a mismatch between the problem text and the provided code. Students could be confused about whether to use Note or Person in the consumer generic type and about what list the consumer receives.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement text and UML to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) for the PersonController methods, and ensure any examples or explanations consistently state that the consumer receives the internal list of Person objects.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, controller behavior) refers to the callback parameter type as Consumer<List<Note>> while both the template and the solution client controllers use Consumer<List<Person>> for PersonController methods. This is a copy/paste naming mismatch (Note vs Person) that can confuse students about the expected generic type for the PersonController callbacks and which internal list is passed to the consumer.
issues.suggested_fix: In the problem statement replace the incorrect Consumer<List<Note>> with Consumer<List<Person>> (or reword to 'a Consumer that accepts the internal list of Person objects'). This aligns the description with the template and solution method signatures and avoids confusion.
